description: From Early Modern English pleasur, plesur, alteration (with ending accommodated to -ure) of Middle English plaisir (“pleasure”), from Old French plesir, plaisir (“to please”), infinitive used as a noun, conjugated form of plaisir or plaire, from Latin placeō (“to please, to seem good”), from the Proto-Indo-European *pleh₂-k- (“wide and flat”). Related to Dutch plezier (“pleasure, fun”). More at please.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A state of being pleased or contented; gratification.
examples: Synonyms: delight, gladness, gratification, happiness, indulgence, satisfaction
He remembered with pleasure his home and family.
I get a lot of pleasure from watching others work hard while I relax.

entries.meaning: (countable) A person, thing or action that causes enjoyment.
examples: It was a pleasure to meet you.
Having a good night's sleep is one of life's little pleasures.
Synonyms: desire, fancy, want, will, wish
What is your pleasure: coffee or tea?

entries.meaning: (formal, uncountable) The will or desire of someone or some agency in power.
examples: to hold an office at pleasure: to hold it indefinitely until it is revoked
to be imprisoned at Her Majesty's pleasure: to be imprisoned indefinitely
at Congress's pleasure: whenever or as long as Congress desires

verbs.description: pleasure (third-person singular simple present pleasures, present participle pleasuring, simple past and past participle pleasured)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give or afford pleasure to.

examples: Johnny pleasured Jackie with his mouth last night.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, dated) To take pleasure; to seek or pursue pleasure.
